body:
A few suggestion for you:

  • You should use JUnit rather than building your own testing mechanism. Rather than returning boolean values and printing error messages you could have very clear test statements like assertEquals("default num1 is zero", 0, new TwoNumbers().getFirstNum())
  • Keep your getters and setters clean: getters should just return the value and setters should just set the value.
  • If there's an error condition such as the argument being outside an expected range then throw and exception rather than returning a boolean.
  • Have unit tests confirming that the correct exceptions are thrown under the right conditions (using JUnit's expected annotation key).

If you start with those changes I suspect your issues will become pretty obvious pretty quickly and you'll be learning better practices from the start.
title: Using Testing Class to see if two integer values fit arguments
